description: From Middle English cruschen (‚Äúto crush, smash, squeeze, squash‚Äù), from Old French croissir (‚Äúto crush‚Äù), from Late Latin *crusci≈ç (‚Äúto brush‚Äù), from Frankish *krostjan (‚Äúto crush, squeeze, squash‚Äù) , from Proto-Germanic *kreustanƒÖ (‚Äúto crush, grind, strike, smash‚Äù).

Akin to Gothic êå∫êçÇêåπêåøêçÉêçÑêå∞êåΩ (kriustan, ‚Äúto gnash‚Äù), Old Swedish krusa (‚Äúto crush‚Äù), Middle Low German krossen (‚Äúto break‚Äù), Swedish krysta (‚Äúto squeeze‚Äù), Danish kryste (‚Äúto squash‚Äù), Icelandic kreista (‚Äúto squeeze, squash‚Äù), Faroese kroysta (‚Äúto squeeze‚Äù).

entries.meaning: A violent collision or compression; a crash; destruction; ruin.
Violent pressure, as of a moving crowd.
A violent crowding.
A crowd that produces uncomfortable pressure.
(slang) A group or gang.
A crowd control barrier.
A drink made by squeezing the juice out of fruit.

definitionGroups.group: (informal) An infatuation with somebody one is not dating.

entries.meaning: (informal, by extension) The human object of such infatuation or affection.
examples: It had taken nine years from the evening that Truman first showed up with a pie plate at her mother's door, but his dogged perseverance eventually won him the hand of his boyhood Sunday school crush.

entries.meaning: A standing stock or cage with movable sides used to restrain livestock for safe handling.
(dated) A party or festive function.
(Australia) The process of crushing cane to remove the raw sugar, or the season when this process takes place.
(television, uncountable) The situation where certain colors are so similar as to be hard to distinguish, either as a deliberate effect or as a limitation of a display.
(uncountable, sexuality) A paraphilia involving arousal from seeing things destroyed by crushing.
examples: Just as they say that marijuana leads to harder drugs, Gallegly is claiming that crush is a "gateway fetish"‚Äîa term I've never heard before. He claims that if someone starts with bugs they'll end up escalating to human babies in no time.

verbs.description: crush (third-person singular simple present crushes, present participle crushing, simple past and past participle crushed)

entries.meaning: To press between two hard objects; to squeeze so as to alter the natural shape or integrity, or to force together into a mass.
To reduce to fine particles by pounding or grinding.
(figurative) To overwhelm by pressure or weight.
examples: After the corruption scandal, the opposition crushed the ruling party in the elections

entries.meaning: (figurative, colloquial) To do impressively well at (sports events; performances; interviews; etc.).
examples: They had a gig recently at Madison Square‚Äîtotally crushed it!

entries.meaning: To oppress or grievously burden.
To overcome completely; to subdue totally.
examples: The sultan's black guard crushed every resistance bloodily.

entries.meaning: (intransitive) To be or become broken down or in, or pressed into a smaller volume or area, by external weight or force.
(intransitive, transitive) To feel infatuation or unrequited love.
(film, television) To give a compressed or foreshortened appearance to.
examples: He frames his subject in distant close-ups (we feel the distance, due mostly to the crushed perspective brought about by the telephoto lens).

entries.meaning: (transitive, television) To make certain colors so similar as to be hard to distinguish, either as a deliberate effect or as a limitation of a display.
examples: My old TV set crushes the blacks when the brightness is lowered.
